title: AI & Creativity: How to Unleash Innovation by Empowering Your Team

rawLines.text: AI is changing everything. How we
create, how we learn, even how we think.
One of the biggest challenges isn't the
technology itself. It's how people adopt
and use it. Many organizations focus on
efficiency and automation. But there's a
much bigger opportunity when we let AI
be a tool for exploration and
experimentation. To dive into this, I'm
joined by Jenny Nicholson, SVP of
creative and strategic innovation at
Movement Strategy and the founder of
Queen of Swords. Jenny spent her career
bridging creativity and technology,
helping brands and individuals use AI in
unexpected ways. She's led experimental
AI projects and is deeply passionate
about AI's role in education, critical
thinking, and human creativity. Jenny,
welcome to Just Caris. Thank you. Thanks
for having me. Awesome. Excited to have
you here. excited to dig into the
intersection of humans and machines.
Tell us maybe to start a little bit more
about yourself and your focus on AI.
Yeah, so I have spent the majority of my
career as a advertising creative.
started as a proofreader, became a
copywriter, moved my way up to creative
director, executive creative director,
and
in 2022, I went out on my own um at
first as a freelance creative and I
found my way into AI. started
experimenting at the I think summer of
2021 and then just really dove in and
started finding myself doing more and
more AI ccentric work to where now most
people think of me as an AI lady which
is a little bit of a hard adjustment
because I'm like no no no I'm a creative
person who loves technology and right
now AI is the most interesting thing I
could be doing so that's what I'm doing
if something that comes out tomorrow
that is equally as interesting that's
what I'll be paying attention to. And
you know, my whole career, I have always
loved technology, which is funny because
I actually spent a good chunk of my
childhood living in the middle of the
woods in Tennessee with no electricity
or running water. Oh, wow. And so I
think it's very funny that I'm like a
technology obsessed person, but what I
love about technology is actually I'm
I'm not generally super interested in
technology for technologies sake. I'm
always interested in how technology
changes humans, changes the way we
connect with people, changes the way we
understand ourselves, changes the way we
move through the world. And that's
always that sort of feedback loop
between technology and humans and each
other. And technology and humans and
each other is what really has always
been interesting to me. Yeah. And I'm
I'm really looking forward to diving
into how we can use AI in a humanistic
way. I'd love to hear a little bit more
about your work. So tell me a little bit
more about Queen of Swords and movement
and what type of work you do and who you
do it for. Okay, so Queen of Swords is
my independent consultancy and you know
when I was working for myself all the
time. I was doing both training and
building. And I was building complex
workflows, building products. AI sort of
infused products coming into kind of
creative projects for ad agencies and
showing them how they could use AI to
actually make more interesting creative
make things that they couldn't have made
before. I'm really interested in work
that lives sort of it's not quite
marketing, it's not quite a product, but
it kind of lives in that space in
between. And as an example, I did a
project with Zola, which is a wedding
planning platform. They do this survey
every year called the first look report
where they basically survey people who
got married over the last year and use
Zola and they ask them questions about
like what basically what sucks the most
about wedding planning, what surprised
you the most. And one of the things that
came out from this was that the single
biggest surprise that people have when
they're planning a wedding is that they
have so many decisions to make. People
are not prepared for the number of
decisions. And the number one pain
point, especially in cisgender,
heterosexual partnerships, is the vast
majority of those decisions fall on one
half of the partnership. I will let the
listeners decide which half that is. You
know, one of the things we learned, we
did a lot of research, went and dug into
Reddit, both people in wedding planning,
but also tried to find men on Reddit.
And what we discovered was it's not that
the men don't want to be part of it.
They don't know where to start. And also
they have just as much as women do this
cultural belief that it's the ladies
thing and the best thing that you can do
is to stay out of the way. So you have
this one group of people who want to be
part of it but are but feel like they're
not supposed to like that's not their
thing and they shouldn't care. And then
you have this other half of the
partnership who's like why am I doing
this all by myself? And we said, "Is
there something we could actually do to
help that?" You know, and we knew we
couldn't like go messing around in their
product when software is your product
like spinning up a new feature is not
easy. It's not something you can do
lightly. And we said, well, what if we
used chat GBT and a custom GPT as like a
testing ground to see what we could do?
And we ended up making a tool that's a
custom GBT called split the decisions.
And it's designed for couples to do
together. and you sit down, ask you some
questions about your wedding, when,
where, about how many people, and ask
each of you the same questions. What are
three words you would describe, use to
describe your feelings about wedding
planning? What are you most excited
about? What are you most worried about?
What do you what do you the one thing
you really want to be part of your
wedding? And what do you want people who
leave your wedding after the reception
to say about the wedding? So, both
partners answer that. And then it asks a
series of which of you questions. Which
of you is most likely to actually enjoy
haggling for a good deal? Yeah. Which of
you is most likely to have a meltdown
over which font to put on the
invitations? And it basically asks, I
don't know, six or seven of those
essentially psychoraphic questions that
don't have anything to do with your
gender role or the task, but are about
like what you're good at, what your
strengths are. And then what it does is
it takes all of your answers and divides
all the tasks up, all the sort of most
common tasks of wedding planning and
divides them equally. One person,
partner A gets half, partner B gets
half, and then there's a group of tasks
like picking your efficient that both of
you get. Yeah. And then it generates for
you a downloadable CSV that has the
task, that has the person it's assigned
to, and that also has a link to a Zola
tool, a Zola article, a Zola resource,
or a Zola product that will help you
actually pull that off. It's cool. And
so for me, that is a the kind of thing
that would not have been able to exist
without AI. Yeah. And it definitely
wouldn't have been able to be something
that you know myself and one person on
the Zola team built it together over the
course of a month. Yeah. I was going to
ask you like so that marketing product
that you created using Generative AI
took you an individual about a month.
Two years ago, how long do you think it
would have taken to put something like
that together? two years ago it probably
wouldn't have even happened because you
know the budget would have been
prohibitive. One of the things that I
always say is like that kind of work,
that thing that is it a product, is it
an experience, is it an ad? Like that's
always been my passion area. But the
problem with that is if I'm trying to
sell, if I'm trying to get a client to
do a TV commercial, right? You buy, you
spend x number of dollars buying space
on television or buying banner ads or
buying social and you say, "If I spend
this amount of money, I know this number
of people will see the thing that I
did." You can't know whether the thing
that they did will actually have the
effect that you want, but you know that
people will see it. You have at least
some certainty. And then when it comes
to television commercials, social posts,
things like that, you have like focus
groups, you have AB testing, you have
all these things that you can do that
kind of reduce the uncertainty of
whether or not this was going to be a
good investment, right? where the kind
of things that I like to build something
like split the decisions. I don't really
have a good way to say this is going to
give you X, Y, and Z. Yeah. Right.
Because I don't have anything to
benchmark it against cuz it's not really
been done before. I don't have it
doesn't come with like a built-in like
media plan that you just spend this
amount of money, you put it in the
bucket, and you know people are going to
see it, which is fine. And and I didn't
have trouble getting getting companies
to understand the value of that. They
they understood the creative potential.
They understood the relationship
potential. They understood why it was a
good idea. Yeah. The problem is is
that's a lot of uncertainty. Yeah. And
then they ask the next question. Do you
I'm assuming you guess what the question
they always want to know is tell us how
much is it going to cost? How long it
take? And then I have to say, well, it's
going to take six months and it's going
to cost $125,000.
Yeah. And that's the end of that
conversation right there. Yeah. And so
now you've created a way to where I can
say it's going to take a month and it's
going to cost $40,000. Yeah. Yeah.
You've reduced $40,000 is enough to be
able to say, you know what, that isn't
that much of a risk. And what we ended
up doing is we launched it as a custom
GPT. got a lot of good press coverage
over that and also was able to use that
thing that we launched as a test to say
is this a product that people are
interested in? Is this a product that
people would want to talk about? Is this
a product that people would use? And
then take the learning from that and
then use that to decide is this a
product that we want to actually invest
in building into our platform proper.
And that's what I think becomes really
exciting is that you can actually go
from idea to thing in the world that
people can experience that they can
engage with that you can learn from.
Whether or not it's working for them,
whether or not it's compelling to them,
whether or not it makes a positive
difference in somebody's life, whether
or not it has a positive impact on how
people think of your company, how people
think of your brand without having to go
all the way to spending months and
months and months and hundreds of
thousands of dollars to get that answer.
Yeah. If one of the barriers to
innovative experimentation is like the
cost, this is dramatically reducing it
and should lead to an explosion in
experimentation. Reminds me actually of
how bubbles tend to lead to a lot of
innovation in that people have a
speculative frenzy. They're much more
willing to explore like back in the late
'9s, you know, what the future of the
internet could look like. Many of those
things don't work out, but because the
cost is so low, people will like pursue
those experiments. And here you have
something similar like if the cost is
low enough, there's no reason not to
experiment absent the fact that of
course people have limited amounts of
time. Yeah, exactly. But you know there
are things that you know a lot of the
things that that I build like lots of
them use AI as part of the thing but a
lot of things that I built are
programmatic that don't use AI but that
because I have AI to partner with I
don't have to necessarily have all of
the technical knowledge of how to do the
programming. I just have to have the
idea. I have to have the willingness to
try and I have to have the patience to
go at the pace that I can go at and the
comfort to ask some generative
computational entity like wait what is
that how do I do that where do I find
that
and when you're willing to do those
things when you that's all you need is
an idea patience and the humility to be
able to say I don't understand can we go
back a step. Wait, what is that? Yeah.
Help me understand that. Don't just do
it for me. Teach me how you're doing it
as we do it. Yeah. That's all you need.
That's literally all you need. Yeah.
It's a game changer. When it comes to
AI, you've told me you think the
mainstream narratives around AI are
wrong. That people think of LMS as a
automated solution that happens separate
from the humans on the team and that's
as you said asked backwards. Uh tell me
tell me what you mean and what people
should be doing. So one of the things
that people when they have a pain that
they think that AI can help make that
pain go away. The question they have is
is there a tool that does this thing?
And often the thing that they're asking
for that tool to do is a big thing. It's
a an entire job. And what I always say
is I'm like no there is not a platform
and thank god there's not because if
there were that would be kind of scary.
But what happens is people have this
mindset where it's like I either do it
myself or I get an AI that does the
whole thing for me. Yeah. And they end
up spending all their time evaluating
platforms, looking at tools, like
researching software as a service
providers, doing demos instead of saying
like, okay, I could do this big tool,
but I don't really understand this
technology very much. What if I just use
the tools that are available to
everybody to better understand how this
technology can support me? Not in the
whole picture, but if I can instead of
getting it to 100% of one thing, right?
That's what everybody does. Like I want
it to do 100% of this part of my job
where I'm like, "No, no, no. I just use
it to help me do everything that I do or
everything that I'm not good at
doing five times faster than I could do
it by myself. And so I don't have any
one thing where I'm like this is my AI
thing. I just raise the bar on
everything that I do, especially on the
places where I'm not strong so that I in
in general get better and faster. Like I
don't have I will never publish
something that AI has written for me
because I'm a writer. Yeah. Why would I
have AI write something for me when it
can never write anything that's going to
be as good as that I would write? And
also like writing is my identity and
giving that up is not something that I
would want to give up. But I'm not a
software developer. I'm not a like
expert in all kinds of random domains.
But I can ask questions about all those
domains that make me smarter about what
I'm writing about. Yeah, that that that
use and those aspirations are driven by
experimentation, your individual
experimentation. One of the other
mainstream narratives is around AI
adoption that it's within enterprise not
high and you said as well that um
adoption is not driven by task force.
It's not a kind of top- down mandate.
It's really about individual
experimentation. Why why do you think
organizations struggle with this?
Because that's how organizations have
always worked, you know, and also
because it's scary. And it's scary to
say, "Oh, wait. We're going to give this
to our frontline day-to-day employees
and give them the freedom, the
permission, and the training to figure
out how to make it work for them." That
requires a a level of of trust and a
level of sort of holding on loosely that
I don't think comes naturally to most
companies. Most companies are like,
"Okay, this new thing is coming. We got
to get a group of like our IT people and
our legal people together and our like
like tech ops people and we're going to
come up with a plan and we're going to
research all the tools and we're going
to find the best tool and we're going to
have them like make something just for
us and like that's going to be the way."
And then you make this thing that's like
your thing that then you have to get
people to use. But you built a thing
that isn't necessarily like most the the
the truth of most organizations is the
people in charge of the organization
don't really actually understand what
it's like to do the actual work, right?
So at movement strategy like the CEO
doesn't know what a junior content
strategist does all day. Like if the CEO
really knew the pain points of the
junior content strategist, they wouldn't
be able to be a CEO, right? They've got
bigger things that they're working on.
For for people in sort of leadership to
sort of pick the tool and how to use the
tool that's supposed to meet the needs
of everybody when what AI is, and when I
say AI, I'm specifically speaking right
now about large language
models. when it is essentially a
polymorphic technology that it shapes
itself to the needs of the user. So, one
of the things that I always say is
instead of using software as a service,
right? It's not like picking a like like
picking between smart sheet in a sauna
and like monday.com. It's not like that.
It's like giving people pencils, right?
You wouldn't be like, "Hello, we have we
have like in some ways a large language
model is like a pencil, right? Just like
a pencil is a tool that has some
fundamental things that are consistent,
but the way that pencil is used is
entirely dependent on the person who's
using the pencil. And you don't you're
not born knowing how to use a pencil,
right? You don't come out of the womb
knowing how to use a pencil. You have to
learn. You have to learn how to sharpen
it. You have to learn how to hold it.
You have to learn what happens if you
press down too hard. What happens if you
don't press down hard enough? You have
to understand the eraser. You have to
understand that sometimes when you try
to erase it smears around everywhere.
Like those are things that you can only
But like once you understand how the
pencil works, you can use the pencil for
whatever the hell you want. And the way
I see it is I'm like, you know who has a
really good idea about what would make
the junior content strategist job
better? Yeah. The junior content
strategist. Yeah. So instead of being
like, "We're going to buy a platform
tool that you all have to use that is
made with people who don't do your job
all day long, who don't know what hurts,
who don't know what you would love to
have, who don't know where you're weak,
who don't know where you're strong,
because all of us are different." Like,
what if instead of that we said, "We're
going to teach you all how to use a
pencil. We're going to give you all
access to a pencil and we're going to
encourage you and we're going to
incentivize you not to use this
particular branded pencil that's blue
with orange stripes and somebody put a
little like you know those like weird
little pencil grip things on it which I
don't really like. We're not going to do
that. We're just going to give you a
pencil. We're going to say use this tool
to make
yourself 20% more badass in whatever way
you see fit. Which one of those is going
to lead to more innovation? Which one of
those is going to lead to more
breakthroughs? And it's not you have to
make yourself 20% more badass to meet
your OKR. It's we're going to
incentivize you to be 20% more badass.
Yeah. How do you not just you have to
teach you have to make the technology
accessible, right? You have to teach
people how to use it and you have to
incentivize them to share what they are
doing and learning. Without those three
things, you will not have adoption.
Yeah. Because a if you're in task force
land trying to find the right tool,
making some bespoke thing, it's like no,
everybody's already using chat GBT on
their personal accounts anyways. If you
block it on their your computer, their
computers, they're using it on their
phone. So just go get people a bunch of
seats on chat GPT team which is designed
for companies which is designed to not

thing is gone. They can make custom GPTs
that they can share with other people
and then incentivize them for doing it.
Celebrate them for doing it. Bonus them
for doing it. Yeah. What have you seen
that look like in practice? And maybe
I'll just play back what you what you
said first. It's about giving people
access to pencils and so that could be
chat GPT teams seats where they have a
space to play around and learn. Two,
it's about I guess learning how to use

three is uh incentives um which could be

mon you know uh mon monetary and uh and
so what does what does that look like in
in practice like what what have you seen
like work in terms of a kind of
threepoint plan like that? So I think
Maderna is a really really good example.
So Maderna uses chat GBT enterprise and
that's what they're using as their
platform and there are some amazing case

like chatbt is for little rinky dinky

on like you need an enterprise solution
blah blah blah blah blah like where most

the like on top of the GPT model
anyways. So there's a lot of noise from

makes decision makers maybe think like
oh this isn't the best thing then you
have a lot of our existing products
trying to like build AI into it right so
now every single time I open Google docs
Gemini is like want me to help you write
that and I'm like no like which means
that that that as users we're getting
pushed like further and further away
from the technology and so it's hard to
evaluate a technology technology that
you don't understand its strengths and

to sell you a SL platform, if you don't

deeply capable of, you're not going to

in buying or is this something that's
actually just one or two layers deep
that now that we have a better
understanding of this technology, we
could probably build it ourselves.
Right. Right. But if you don't have the
basic understanding of what it is in its
most sort of fundamental form, how can
you evaluate? And then on the sort of
incentivizing side, it's like access.
People are already using CHABT in their
life. So why not have them using it for
work where they're already most
comfortable using it? Yeah. Then on the
knowing side, not only does it make them
better at using the technology if you
train them how to use HBT, they also get
more savvy about evaluating the millions
of sale pitches that every company is
getting barried with from SAS vendors
selling bespoke solutions. And then
thirdly, on the incentivizing side, one
of the things that is very real is that
even advanced people, there is this
feeling that I feel like I'm cheating. I
feel like I'm getting away with
something. I feel like if I tell my
company what I'm doing, they're going to
give me tons more work. They're going to
ask me what I'm doing all day. They're
going to be like, "Oh, if you can use AI
to do this, you can replace me." And so,
there's a psychological factor that
keeps even the people who are using it
maybe at more advanced levels in your
company than you would know. They have
no incentive or motivation to be public,
honest, and open about the use that
they're doing, about what they're doing,
which means nobody else in the
organization can learn from them. Yeah.
Yeah. How do you give them that
permission just explicitly like you know
we we we want you to become more

efficiency. We're not going to punish

happens. Most companies make like using

something that you have to do. They make
it something you have to do. And right
now, so many people in the world are
looking at this technology and they're
coming at it from a place of fear, which
is so understandable because it's
weird. Excuse my language. Like,
this is a very different thing. Like I
like to say, you know, you can talk
about what it is, you can talk about how

well or better than we do with meaning
that it can say something to me that I

existentially it's existent. It's
existential. So there's this existential
layer of fear. Yeah. Right. Where it's
like what does it mean to be human? Like
what who am I? Like there is this like
very deep feeling. Not to mention that
we've all been trained on generations of

goes into the belly of the machine and

have an existential good relationship
with technology. Yeah. Then you get to

you've got somebody who's now a huge

you have to find time to learn this new

then it becomes this thing that you have
to do to stay competitive to protect

do those sound like good conditions for

the existential threat feels real and
also uh nearer term? And I think it's
like so part of my experience is in

person. So the first thing that I do
when I sit down with this technology is
I'm like what can I do with it that's
not in the manual? Yeah. And that's one
of the things that's that's got me to
this idea that this mainstream narrative
is backwards. I'll get I got there
eventually.
is backwards because it's all about
efficiency. It's all about productivity.
It's all about how can we do what we're
doing faster, cheaper, and with fewer
humans. Like we have the this new
polymorphic technology that is the first
time something like this has been
available to any of us in the world that
can actually manipulate language with
meaning. And what we're doing is being
like, how do we use it to do what we're
already doing faster? Yeah, that's how
we're using it. Where the way I like to
think about it is I like to think about
a large language model as like at the
same time it is it is a book, it is a
library, it is a librarian all at once.
Yeah. And I can wander through the
library and look at any particular book,
but also the book is a librarian. So it
can tell me what other books I might
like. Yeah. So for example, if I'm
working on um you know, I work in
advertising, so I'll just use a that's a
metaphor that's relevant to me. I'm
working on a brief, right? Where I'm
like, okay, our business problem is
this. The people we're trying to reach
is this, and the thing we really want
them to know about us is this, right?
Most people's tendency is to go in and
be like, give me a brief for this
business problem talking to this
audience that the main takeaway is this,
right? And they get a brief and it's
going to be a shitty brief cuz the model
doesn't know. It's giving you literally
the most likely thing that you would
get. And part of being a creative
person, but also part of being a
business person in general, is you're
not looking for the thing that everybody
says. You're looking for the thing that
nobody has seen yet, the thing that
nobody has looked for yet, the thing
that nobody has found yet. And just

cleanText:
AI is changing everything. How we create, how we learn, even how we think. One of the biggest challenges isn't the technology itself. It's how people adopt and use it. Many organizations focus on efficiency and automation, but there's a much bigger opportunity when we let AI be a tool for exploration and experimentation. To dive into this, I'm joined by Jenny Nicholson, SVP of creative and strategic innovation at Movement Strategy and the founder of Queen of Swords. Jenny spent her career bridging creativity and technology, helping brands and individuals use AI in unexpected ways. She's led experimental AI projects and is deeply passionate about AI's role in education, critical thinking, and human creativity. Jenny, welcome to Just Curious. Thank you. Thanks for having me. Awesome. Excited to have you here. Excited to dig into the intersection of humans and machines. Tell us maybe to start a little bit more about yourself and your focus on AI.

Yeah, so I have spent the majority of my career as an advertising creative. I started as a proofreader, became a copywriter, moved my way up to creative director, executive creative director, and in 2022, I went out on my own, um, at first as a freelance creative, and I found my way into AI. I started experimenting at the, I think, summer of 2021 and then just really dove in and started finding myself doing more and more AI-centric work to where now most people think of me as an AI lady, which is a little bit of a hard adjustment because I'm like, no, no, no, I'm a creative person who loves technology, and right now AI is the most interesting thing I could be doing, so that's what I'm doing. If something that comes out tomorrow that is equally as interesting, that's what I'll be paying attention to. And you know, my whole career, I have always loved technology, which is funny because I actually spent a good chunk of my childhood living in the middle of the woods in Tennessee with no electricity or running water. Oh, wow. And so I think it's very funny that I'm like a technology-obsessed person, but what I love about technology is actually, I'm not generally super interested in technology for technology's sake. I'm always interested in how technology changes humans, changes the way we connect with people, changes the way we understand ourselves, changes the way we move through the world. And that's always that sort of feedback loop between technology and humans and each other. And technology and humans and each other is what really has always been interesting to me. Yeah. And I'm really looking forward to diving into how we can use AI in a humanistic way. I'd love to hear a little bit more about your work. So tell me a little bit more about Queen of Swords and movement and what type of work you do and who you do it for. Okay, so Queen of Swords is my independent consultancy and you know when I was working for myself all the time, I was doing both training and building. And I was building complex workflows, building products, AI sort of infused products coming into kind of creative projects for ad agencies and showing them how they could use AI to actually make more interesting creative, make things that they couldn't have made before. I'm really interested in work that lives sort of, it's not quite marketing, it's not quite a product, but it kind of lives in that space in between. And as an example, I did a project with Zola, which is a wedding planning platform. They do this survey every year called the first look report where they basically survey people who got married over the last year and use Zola and they ask them questions about like what basically what sucks the most about wedding planning, what surprised you the most. And one of the things that came out from this was that the single biggest surprise that people have when they're planning a wedding is that they have so many decisions to make. People are not prepared for the number of decisions. And the number one pain point, especially in cisgender, heterosexual partnerships, is the vast majority of those decisions fall on one half of the partnership. I will let the listeners decide which half that is. You know, one of the things we learned, we did a lot of research, went and dug into Reddit, both people in wedding planning, but also tried to find men on Reddit. And what we discovered was it's not that the men don't want to be part of it. They don't know where to start. And also they have just as much as women do this cultural belief that it's the ladies' thing and the best thing that you can do is to stay out of the way. So you have this one group of people who want to be part of it but are but feel like they're not supposed to, like that's not their thing and they shouldn't care. And then you have this other half of the partnership who's like, why am I doing this all by myself? And we said, "Is there something we could actually do to help that?" You know, and we knew we couldn't like go messing around in their product when software is your product, like spinning up a new feature is not easy. It's not something you can do lightly. And we said, well, what if we used ChatGPT and a custom GPT as like a testing ground to see what we could do? And we ended up making a tool that's a custom GPT called split the decisions. And it's designed for couples to do together. And you sit down, ask you some questions about your wedding, when, where, about how many people, and ask each of you the same questions. What are three words you would describe, use to describe your feelings about wedding planning? What are you most excited about? What are you most worried about? What do you, what do you the one thing you really want to be part of your wedding? And what do you want people who leave your wedding after the reception to say about the wedding? So, both partners answer that. And then it asks a series of which of you questions. Which of you is most likely to actually enjoy haggling for a good deal? Yeah. Which of you is most likely to have a meltdown over which font to put on the invitations? And it basically asks, I don't know, six or seven of those essentially psychographic questions that don't have anything to do with your gender role or the task, but are about like what you're good at, what your strengths are. And then what it does is it takes all of your answers and divides all the tasks up, all the sort of most common tasks of wedding planning and divides them equally. One person, partner A gets half, partner B gets half, and then there's a group of tasks like picking your efficient that both of you get. Yeah. And then it generates for you a downloadable CSV that has the task, that has the person it's assigned to, and that also has a link to a Zola tool, a Zola article, a Zola resource, or a Zola product that will help you actually pull that off. It's cool. And so for me, that is a the kind of thing that would not have been able to exist without AI. Yeah. And it definitely wouldn't have been able to be something that, you know, myself and one person on the Zola team built it together over the course of a month. Yeah. I was going to ask you, like, so that marketing product that you created using Generative AI took you an individual about a month. Two years ago, how long do you think it would have taken to put something like that together? Two years ago, it probably wouldn't have even happened because, you know, the budget would have been prohibitive. One of the things that I always say is like that kind of work, that thing that is it a product, is it an experience, is it an ad? Like that's always been my passion area. But the problem with that is if I'm trying to sell, if I'm trying to get a client to do a TV commercial, right? You buy, you spend x number of dollars buying space on television or buying banner ads or buying social and you say, "If I spend this amount of money, I know this number of people will see the thing that I did." You can't know whether the thing that they did will actually have the effect that you want, but you know that people will see it. You have at least some certainty. And then when it comes to television commercials, social posts, things like that, you have like focus groups, you have AB testing, you have all these things that you can do that kind of reduce the uncertainty of whether or not this was going to be a good investment, right? Where the kind of things that I like to build something like split the decisions, I don't really have a good way to say this is going to give you X, Y, and Z. Yeah. Right. Because I don't have anything to benchmark it against 'cause it's not really been done before. I don't have, it doesn't come with like a built-in like media plan that you just spend this amount of money, you put it in the bucket, and you know people are going to see it, which is fine. And and I didn't have trouble getting getting companies to understand the value of that. They they understood the creative potential. They understood the relationship potential. They understood why it was a good idea. Yeah. The problem is is that's a lot of uncertainty. Yeah. And then they ask the next question. Do you, I'm assuming you guess what the question they always want to know is, tell us how much is it going to cost? How long it take? And then I have to say, well, it's going to take six months and it's going to cost $125,000.
Yeah. And that's the end of that conversation right there. Yeah. And so now you've created a way to where I can say it's going to take a month and it's going to cost $40,000. Yeah. Yeah. You've reduced $40,000 is enough to be able to say, you know what, that isn't that much of a risk. And what we ended up doing is we launched it as a custom GPT, got a lot of good press coverage over that and also was able to use that thing that we launched as a test to say, is this a product that people are interested in? Is this a product that people would want to talk about? Is this a product that people would use? And then take the learning from that and then use that to decide, is this a product that we want to actually invest in building into our platform proper. And that's what I think becomes really exciting is that you can actually go from idea to thing in the world that people can experience, that they can engage with, that you can learn from. Whether or not it's working for them, whether or not it's compelling to them, whether or not it makes a positive difference in somebody's life, whether or not it has a positive impact on how people think of your company, how people think of your brand without having to go all the way to spending months and months and months and hundreds of thousands of dollars to get that answer. Yeah. If one of the barriers to innovative experimentation is like the cost, this is dramatically reducing it and should lead to an explosion in experimentation. Reminds me actually of how bubbles tend to lead to a lot of innovation in that people have a speculative frenzy. They're much more willing to explore like back in the late '90s, you know, what the future of the internet could look like. Many of those things don't work out, but because the cost is so low, people will like pursue those experiments. And here you have something similar, like if the cost is low enough, there's no reason not to experiment, absent the fact that, of course, people have limited amounts of time. Yeah, exactly. But you know, there are things that, you know, a lot of the things that that I build, like lots of them use AI as part of the thing, but a lot of things that I built are programmatic that don't use AI, but that because I have AI to partner with, I don't have to necessarily have all of the technical knowledge of how to do the programming. I just have to have the idea. I have to have the willingness to try and I have to have the patience to go at the pace that I can go at and the comfort to ask some generative computational entity like, wait, what is that? How do I do that? Where do I find that? And when you're willing to do those things, when you, that's all you need is an idea, patience, and the humility to be able to say, I don't understand, can we go back a step? Wait, what is that? Yeah. Help me understand that. Don't just do it for me. Teach me how you're doing it as we do it. Yeah. That's all you need. That's literally all you need. Yeah. It's a game changer. When it comes to AI, you've told me you think the mainstream narratives around AI are wrong. That people think of LLMs as a automated solution that happens separate from the humans on the team and that's as you said, asked backwards. Uh, tell me, tell me what you mean and what people should be doing. So one of the things that people, when they have a pain that they think that AI can help make that pain go away, the question they have is, is there a tool that does this thing? And often the thing that they're asking for that tool to do is a big thing. It's a an entire job. And what I always say is, I'm like, no, there is not a platform, and thank God there's not, because if there were, that would be kind of scary. But what happens is people have this mindset where it's like, I either do it myself or I get an AI that does the whole thing for me. Yeah. And they end up spending all their time evaluating platforms, looking at tools, like researching software as a service providers, doing demos instead of saying, like, okay, I could do this big tool, but I don't really understand this technology very much. What if I just use the tools that are available to everybody to better understand how this technology can support me? Not in the whole picture, but if I can instead of getting it to 100% of one thing, right? That's what everybody does. Like I want it to do 100% of this part of my job, where I'm like, "No, no, no. And so I don't have any one thing where I'm like, this is my AI thing. I just raise the bar on everything that I do, especially on the places where I'm not strong so that I in in general get better and faster.
